embeds.title: Firestarter
embeds.description:
Common Attack / 1 :e_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

Deal 6 (8) damage and apply 6 (8) **Soulburn** :p_soulburn: to ALL enemies.

messages.content: decent aoe damage, but I would only take it early act 1
isnt this 12 dmg aoe?
Soulburn is slower and hexa has better access to it
it's a Cleave+, but you only get half the damage now and the other half in 3 turns

acutally terrible. When I first saw this card I figured it would be like cleave or dagger spray but its not, its a scam. You see those cards are used in fights like Gremlin gang or slime gang to end the fight as quickly as possible by taking out half of the health of the little guys all at once. But this card needs to wait for the soul burn to stack up and you don't want to wait for soul burn when gremlin gang is hitting you for 25 damage a turn
theres also sentrys, the other early game group fight thats important, but they have artifact anyways so you have to play this card twice and wait 6 turns
well this card works very well against Hermit 1
because you do damage to both him and his pet louse and 3 turns later do more damage
so does any other soulburn card though, we have things like common 14 soul burn (which is upgraded to 22 soulburn, like what)
what card
<Burning Touch>

messages.content: also I've used Firestarter and it isn't bad
Although its uncommon, living bomb does a better job at making your soulburn live in AOE fights
I've only ever taken firestarter when I have no attacks at all and just need something to smack enemy with
its a shame too, because hexaghost has a crippling AOE weakness, but this card just anit it.

I think it isn't a horrible card in a vacuum, but as you said it has its delayed damage making it tough to wipe out enemies fast, and sentries have artifact. I'd say the fact that it also needs to compete with sword of night in the hexa common attack pool is really unfortunate for it.
The night cards are both extremely good.
It's bad against sentries, gremlin leader and reptomancer, three fights where AoEs should be exceptionally good
It's even worse against single target
It's just pretty bad in general

it works well against Hermit 1?
that's about it
I'll still take it sometimes but it falls off late game, and isn't even that good early game.
Whereas hexa has a lot of commons that really shine in the late game
The fact that half of it's damage is nullified by artifact makes it even worse in the few fights it could potentially work
The one thing it does is that it gets soulburn on the enemy. That helps <thermal transfer> and <burning touch> which are 2 actually good hexa commons

messages.content: If you're fighting many enemies you either want to focus on the most dangerous one, the one you can take out instantly or use the aoe to maximize damage per attack and soften everyone so that you can take them all out on the next 1-2 turns
Hexa just has ungodly powerful commons, and this isn't one of them.
hexaghost players when a common card has 1458 dmg for 1 energy (its bad compared to other commons)

If you really want to depend on soulburn aoe to deal damage then <Flames from Beyond> is infinitely better

messages.content: Not really
Yes but it makes ALL soulburn on said enemy aoe, bot just the living bomb damage
The main point of living bomb is to sack as much SB on a one target as possible so that you nuke everyone else with that damage
Idk, I used to never take it but after the first pick I get to feel it very good. and not a single pick after that made me regret

Firestarter is a strange card. AOE is certainly an important tool to have in most decks, because some of the toughest fights involve dealing with multiple enemies (gremlin gang, slime gang, tri slavers, gremlin leader, reptomancer). However, the reason that you want AOE in your deck is to quickly deal with the low health, high damage enemies so that you are under less pressure to block. This is why bowling bash can be an excellent solution to AOE fights even though it only deals damage to one target. If there are three enemies and you can spend 1 energy to deal 21 damage (30 upgraded, 42 in wrath, 60 if upgraded and in wrath) to a single enemy, you have just made the fight much easier, and your health is under far less pressure. Firestarter is at the opposite end of the spectrum, dealing only 6 AOE damage upfront, making you wait 3 more turns to deal the other 6 damage. Realistically you just never want to be fighting multiple enemies for that long, reptomancer daggers will have blown up in your face, gremlin leaders minions will have received a bunch of buffs, tri slavers will have killed you already, etc. This is also a huge problem for the Bomb, waiting that long for your AOE damage to happen misses the entire point of putting AOE in your deck in the first place. If you have 1-2 copies of the 0 cost card that detonates soulburn right away, this could become more appealing, but in general you would much rather have the afterlife AOE card
the afterlife aoe cards being <spectre's wail> and <flames from beyond>

embeds.title: Specter's Wail
embeds.description:
Common Attack / 1 :e_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

**Ethereal**. **Afterlife.**

embeds.title: Flames from Beyond
embeds.description:
Uncommon Skill / 2 :e_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

**Ethereal**. **Afterlife.**
Apply 18 (24) **Soulburn** :p_soulburn: to ALL enemies.

messages.content: Spectre's wail does almost the same amount of damage but all immediately, and has afterlife as well.

Generally speaking, **Firestarter** is a card that was designed to apply the first instance of **Soulburn** to the enemies, so it is expected that it might be weird in AoE fights, but the fact that it applies **Soulburn** to ALL enemies helps when it comes to dealing with them.

It is pretty good to pick, but as said previously it is pretty slow, so you need to combo it with **Phantom Fireball** or a **Searing Wound** to turn it into a card that becomes a good solution for AoE scenarios.
Also it can be used as an **Artifact** stripper if you picked cards that apply much bigger amounts of **Soulburn**.
